title: Counter terrorism police investigated claims of 'Trojan Horse' plot at Oldham primary school
text:
News Counter terrorism police investigated claims of 'Trojan Horse' plot at Oldham primary school In one case, the headteacher reported threats to blow up her car, according to a report by Oldham council Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Counter terrorism police have launched an investigation into fears of a ‘Trojan Horse-style’ plot at a primary school in Oldham. 
Clarksfield Primary School has been at the centre of an investigation into allegations of an ‘Islamic plot’ to take over the school, as well as claims of threats made towards headteacher, Trish O’Donnell. 
Ms O’Donnell, head of Clarksfield Primary since 2006, raised concerns for her personal safety with Oldham Council in December. Read More Two men arrested on suspicion of attempted murder after man shot outside Moss Side pub 
The head said she had been forced to work from home after being subjected to ‘death threats’, aggressive verbal abuse and even a physical attack, it is understood. 
In one case, she reported threats to blow up her car, according to a report by Oldham council. Trish O'Donnell 
She said in the correspondence that she believed her position was untenable and a “Trojan horse” agenda was underway. 
A ‘major’ fall out between Ms O’Donnell and a new chair of Governors is also understood to have added to tensions at the school in recent months. 
Bosses at Oldham Council confirmed an investigation into Ms O’Donnell’s claim had been carried out. Read More Could your fiver be worth £50,000? There's just one rare Jane Austen note left in circulation in England... 
Yet a council spokesman said they found ‘no basis’ in the Trojan Horse allegations. 
They also referred the allegations to the counter terrorism unit at Greater Manchester Police, who launched their own investigation into the claims and the Department for Education. 
A police spokesman said the relevant authorities were still looking into the matter. Debbie Abrahams (Photo: Andy Commins/Daily Mirror) 
Debbie Abrahams, MP for Oldham East and Saddleworth, said the duty placed on teachers to carry out the Government’s counter-terrorism Prevent strategy was ‘fraught with difficulties.’ 
Speaking to the MEN, Ms Abrahams said: “I understand that investigations into harassment of the head teacher at Clarksfield Primary School have been undertaken by Oldham Council and also Greater Manchester Police (GMP). 
“I also understand that allegations that this amounted to a ‘Trojan horse’ plot have been investigated by Oldham Council, linking in with GMP’s Counter Terrorism Unit, and the Department for Education’s Compliance Unit, who concluded that there was no evidence to support this claim. Read More Morrisons recalls meat product after tests show it contains Listeria bug that could cause meningitis 
“We must, of course, be vigilant to any issues that could conflate community tensions. This is why, along with the council, other Oldham MPs, organisations and leaders, we continually work across our diverse communities whilst tackling underlying inequalities which ultimately fuel these tensions. 
“Unfortunately the new Prevent duty placed on educators to report people at risk of radicalisation is fraught with difficulties, as has been raised by David Anderson, the independent reviewer of terrorist legislation.” 
Coun Amanda Chadderton, Cabinet Member for Education and Early Years, added: “We take any allegations about our schools very seriously and always investigate in the interests of pupils, staff and parents. 
“The report into an Oldham primary school found no basis to the ‘Trojan Horse’ allegations. 
“At this time we also have no active investigations or concerns about any of the other schools the Sunday Times has asked about.” 
A GMP spokesperson said: “GMP has received information obtained by partners regarding a school in Oldham. We have passed on information to the relevant authorities which are looking into the matter.” 
A DfE spokesperson said: “We are already aware of the allegations raised in the report and we are working closely with Oldham council.” 
The Manchester Evening News has tried to contact Ms O’Donnell. Like us on Facebook
